body.p: On the organ scale, sheets of epithelial cells organize themselves into plicae circulares, which are permanent, ridges or folks inside the small intestine. These folds increase surface area for a given length of small intestine, which allows increased absorption. The function of most of the structures inside the small intestine is to increase surface area for absorption.

Villi are small (0.5-1 mm long) finger-like projections on the lumen surface of absorptive epithelial cells of the small intestine. There are about 20 to 40 villi per square millimeter, increasing the surface area of the epithelium tremendously. The increase in surface area allows for a more rapid and efficient rate of absorption when digestive material is present in the lumen of the small intestine. In the core of each villus is a blood capillary network and a lymphatic capillary called a lacteal, so absorbed material can access the bloodstream for transport throughout the body. Lacteals are needed for fat absorption since emulsified fats are often too big to passively enter capillaries.

Microvilli are small (1 Âµm) cylindrical extensions of the plasma member of the mucosa's absorptive cells. The combined microvilli give the mucosal surface a "fuzzy" appearance, which is called the brush border. The plasma membranes of the microvilli include brush-border enzymes that finish digesting carbohydrates and proteins. There are an estimated 200 million microvilli per square millimeter of small intestine, greatly expanding the surface area of the plasma membrane and thus greatly enhancing absorption.
